awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Wearable Non-Invasive Deep Tissue Thermometer
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to measure biological temperatures for many important problems in health care, by advancing a novel temperature sensor.   In the near term, a wearable, non-invasive sensor can prevent heat stroke and exhaustion for at-risk cohorts, such as the US military, which suffers from 2800 annual cases of heat stroke in active-duty personnel.  Furthermore, heat stroke early warning could diminish injuries and deaths among U.S. high school and college athletes and 7.4 million first responders who typically operate under stressful conditions. Beyond heat stress, this thermometer can monitor elevated brain temperature during the critical hours following stroke or traumatic brain injury (affecting 4.8 million patients per year), which can cause additional brain damage and permanent disabilities. The proposed sensor can directly measure tumor temperature during heating therapy, potentially improving clinical outcomes for some of the 1.8 million patients per year by 20-40% while reducing dosage of debilitating chemicals and radiation.  

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will demonstrate a novel, non-invasive temperature sensor capable of accurately measuring deep tissue temperature several centimeters below the skin, wherever placed. The proposed sensor detects small microwave signals in a noisy environment by incorporating 20+ signal processing and noise reduction methods with technologies similar to those used in radio astronomy. Non-invasive brain temperature measurement is particularly important as the brain generates and manages its own critical operating temperature, and elusive as it can only be inferred from surrogate measurements without directly cutting into the skull. Direct brain temperature monitoring with a wearable device may provide early warning of many health conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
A Wearable Non-Invasive Deep Tissue Thermometer
LumenAstra - NSF SBIR Phase I Outcomes

Project Overview

LumenAstra is commercializing a patent from the University of Colorado for a non-invasive, wearable sensor for measuring internal temperature several centimeters below the skin, wherever placed.  When placed on the forehead, our sensor will directly measure brain temperature in real-time.  There currently is no method for measuring true internal temperatures without highly invasive sensor tipped needles or catheters. 

Over 200 interviews with potential customers uncovered more than a dozen impactful applications covering clinical, military, consumer and professional uses.

Our first target application measures brain temperature during aortic dissection surgery with a 17% mortality rate and high risk of stroke and cognitive loss. This surgery requires deep cooling to protect the brain while shutting off the blood supply. The time-at-cold is directly correlated to these risks.

Surgeons are enthusiastic that our sensor will cut 15-20 minutes off surgical time which could reduce mortality by 20%.

Outcomes

Key outcomes of our NSF Phase I project include:

1. Evaluation of different sensor architectures:  Our sensor leverages the science that all objects radiate electromagnetic power proportional to temperature. During Phase I, we were able to simulate and build prototypes for testing competing architectures for their sensitivity and accuracy at measuring tiny amounts of microwave power generated by deep tissues. (On the order of femtowatts, 10-15 watts!!) As a result, we developed a new and promising hybrid radiometer design leading to a new patent. We also created a new antenna design tuned to work well on the forehead delivering excellent temperature information from brain matter. (Figure 1)

2. Progress in miniaturization:  We had successfully demonstrated the science with a large lab prototype with discrete off-the-shelf components.  The Phase I project allowed us to miniaturize our device through progressively smaller prototypes to reach a credit-card size approaching our commercial target of less than 50mm diameter. (Figure 2) Our next Phase II of the project will incorporate state-of-the-art Gallium Arsenide chips that we piloted and tested during Phase I combining many discrete components into a proprietary package. (Figure 3)

3. Determined minimum integration time:  An important aspect of the Phase I project was to investigate and understand the minimum measurement time necessary to obtain the accuracy, stability and resolution needed. Our prototypes demonstrated that we were making stable, repeatable measurements with 1-2 seconds of measurement time, quite appropriate for slowly changing biological temperatures and meeting the commercial market requirements expressed through customer interviews. (Figure 4)

4. Significant progress in temperature calibration: The fundamental reason prior attempts at using radiometry to measure internal body temperature failed was due to an inability to properly convert broadband electromagnetic power radiated from within the body into a calibrated temperature. Our patent combines a near-field probe specifically designed to match underlying tissue layers allowing calibration of the measured power by the electromagnetic characteristics of each layer and boundaries. Through simulation and testing with phantom targets, we have arrived at a high-performance sensor design meeting our requirements along with a thorough understanding of the effects of tissue variations. (Figure 5)

5. Two new patents: Our research and discoveries during the Phase I project have led to two new patents currently in process.  The first is based on a dynamically tunable multi-frequency radiometer allowing isolation of specific tissue layers and increased accuracy of temperature calibration.  The 2nd patent covers a dual-probe version of our device increasing 3D resolution of temperature and contributing to mitigation of external signal interference.

Societal Impact

We discovered during customer interviews that our conversation quickly pivoted from 'core body temperature' to 'targeted tissue temperature'.  The ability to directly measure brain matter temperature in real-time with a wearable device will not only provide increased safety in many types of surgery but will also provide a unique research tool for better understanding the relationship of brain temperature to other health and wellness conditions never before possible. Future applications beyond aortic surgery include:

(Figure 6)

1, Avoiding elevated brain temperature after brain trauma: Elevated brain temperature in the critical 24-hours after stroke and brain trauma lead to additional permanent brain damage.  Today, invasive nasal, esophageal, and bladder temperatures are used as surrogates for brain temperature. Brain protection cooling can be more precisely administered with our sensor.

2. Improving efficacy of cancer therapies:  Studies show a 20-40% increases in efficacy of radiation and chemo-therapy for solid tumors when warmed to 41-43?C. Current methods require highly invasive sensor-tipped needles inserted through the skin into the tumor. Our wearable sensor combined with external heating devices form a closed loop solution. 

3. Quantifying circadian conditions and wellness:  We have conducted many surveys with physicians and therapists working with sleep apnea, diabetes, fertility monitoring and other circadian related conditions. Our sensor will be a significant tool for diagnosis and treatment of these conditions.

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2022
Modified by: James W Pollock

Images (1 of )
  • This illustrates brain temperature measurement with a wearable near-field probe connected to a hybrid radiometer designed for clinical or consumer applications.
    Popovic
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    James W Pollock
    Probe on Forehead Measuring Brain Temperature
  • Images showing miniaturization from early wooden lab prototype to index card sized, to credit card sized to half-credit card sized at end of Phase I
    Streeter, Lee, Pollock
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    James W Pollock
    Miniaturization Over Evolving Prototypes
  • Sketch of concept for near-future version of our wearable sensor showing multi-layer board with probe laminated on one side and circuitry on opposite side. Under 50mm in diameter.
    Pollock
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    James W Pollock
    Concept for Next Generation Device
  • Prototypes were tested with a phantom hot water batch target showing measurement integration time of 2ms, 50ms, 500ms to 5sec. No change in stability after 500ms, meaning 1-2 seconds is good target measurement range.
    Streeter, Hall, Popovic
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    James W Pollock
    Measurement Integration Time
  • Tissue thickness varies from person to person and between body locations. Simulations were run across physiological range of thicknesses found in the human head as shown in table on the left.The simulated profiles show the differences in volume power density determining calibration weightings.
    Streeter, Hall, Popovic
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    James W Pollock
    Radiation Sensitivity vs Variable Tissue Thicknesses
  • This matrix shows results from over 200 customer discovery interviews rankling various market and technical factors affecting opportunity and challenges in the many applications for our wearable temperature sensor. We pivoted from military heat stress to surgical brain temperature during Phase I.
    Pollock
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    James W Pollock
    Matrix for Market Prioritization
